post.title: In my dream, I killed Bi'ru
post.content:
In my dream I killed Bi'ru / 2022 Single Channel Video, color, sound



In this video, Shuhan Ye sets the time point in the future, exploring anthropocentrism from an anti-utopian perspective. The film shows an anti-utopian perspective on the programmed reproduction of humans, the animals forced to live parasitically in human life, and the franticness among every creature.

This is not only a shaping of the flora and fauna but also a linkage to the way the human world will operate in the future. It makes us think: will the future of humanity evolve into a world of ‘anti-utopian’ claims, just as we are reconstructing the The non-human world today?



Bi’ru is a new name given by Shuhan Ye in the video. In Chinese, the word ‘Bi’ru’ is homophonic with ‘for example’. Shuhan Ye has blurred the use of ‘Bi’ru’ as an example or as a name in her video.

The name Bi’ru refers narrowly to the anthropocentric perspective of plants and animals, but broadly to all carbon-based organisms, including humans themselves. The blurring of the boundaries of Bi’ru is meant to be a thought provoking joke, in which the fundamental anthropocentric opposition between humans and animals is blurred and blended into one.



The prayer wheel is a musical instrument in Tibetan Buddhism, and each revolution of the wheel represents a chanting of a sutra, a blessing. In the video, the rotation of the wheel is combined with the rotation of the magazine when changing ammunition in a pistol. The two seemingly unrelated events are absurdly linked in Ye Shuhan's image through the gesture of the spinning hand.
